person.note: This is a straightforward transliteration, with no declension.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
̓Αρσάμης is how this Persian name is transliterated in Greek (WGE, 144).
So according to Epiphanius, in the Syriac script (Wendland, Aristeae, 143), see Introduction 2.8.3.

On Arist see Introduction 6.2.1 and Cohen, JSJ 15 (1984) 35-6, n. 10. The form ̓Αρσάμης is recorded elsewhere in Egyptian antiquity (Preisigke, NB, 54). The Hebrew ארשם is recorded in Egypt too (TADAE4, nos. 6.7, 8, 16, probably all referring to the same man).
For dating of Arist see Introduction 7.1.1.
See above, n. 2

note.ref: See above, n. 3. So according to Epiphanius, in the Syriac script (Wendland, Aristeae, 143), see Introduction 2.8.3.

See above, n. 4. On Arist see Introduction 6.2.1 and Cohen, JSJ 15 (1984) 35-6, n. 10. The form ̓Αρσάμης is recorded elsewhere in Egyptian antiquity (Preisigke, NB, 54). The Hebrew ארשם is recorded in Egypt too (TADAE4, nos. 6.7, 8, 16, probably all referring to the same man).
See above, n. 5. For dating of Arist see Introduction 7.1.1.

person.note: Rahmani, CJO, has אשוני. Misgav, Ossuaries, 68, suggests this reading because it has parallels in the names of amoraim (e.g. אשיין – yYoma 8:7, 45b; אשייאן – yAZ 3:1, 42b; Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 141-2). אשין/אשינא means “to be substantial, dense, strong” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 129). Because the name is recorded in Hebrew, the suffix can be influenced by Aramization, see Introduction 2.4.1. אשנא is mentioned on several Hebrew First Temple seals (CWSSS nos. 5, 99, 100). All this evidence does not contradict a Persian provenance for the name.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. Rahmani, CJO, has אשוני. Misgav, Ossuaries, 68, suggests this reading because it has parallels in the names of amoraim (e.g. אשיין – yYoma 8:7, 45b; אשייאן – yAZ 3:1, 42b; Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 141-2). אשין/אשינא means “to be substantial, dense, strong” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 129). Because the name is recorded in Hebrew, the suffix can be influenced by Aramization, see Introduction 2.4.1. אשנא is mentioned on several Hebrew First Temple seals (CWSSS nos. 5, 99, 100). All this evidence does not contradict a Persian provenance for the name.

person.note: Named after his grandfather (Ašnā no. 1), see Introduction 3.1.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 3. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: On this name see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 331.
Klein, ibid., identifies him with the son of the proselyte (Gamaliel no. 10) mentioned in AdRN 1:15, but this is not very likely. On Klein’s identifications see Introduction 3.3.
This could also be construed as a nickname, see Introduction 6.1.1.
A בן בג בג is mentioned in the Mishnah, Tosefta and PT, but only in bQid 10b is he described as a contemporary of R. Judah ben Batira, who is of the Yabneh generation, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
This is not a recorded Greek name. WGE, 190, mentions a city in Ethiopia by the name of Βάγαδα.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

The two are alternative readings. On this name, see Schlatter HN, 24. Justi, INB, 56, explains the Greek Μεγα/Μαγα as being authentically interchangeable with the Iranian “Baga”. For this particular name see Justi, INB, 57. On double and single letters (δ) see Introduction 2.3.4. The name מגדא/מגדו is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 606-7).

note.ref: See above, n. 3. On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

person.note: In LXX the form Βαγοείis used for בגוי. In Judith 12:11, however, the form Βαγώαςis recorded (H & R Suppl. 31). This is also how this Persian name was transliterated into Greek (WGE, 190). This name was apparently used for eunuchs (Justi, INB, 60). It is interesting to note that the person here mentioned by this name is also a eunuch.
In Greek – ε̓νοῦχος.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
The form בוה is recorded in 5th C BCE Persian Egypt (TADAE3, 4.2). On the ין suffix see Introduction 2.4.3. On this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 331.
This could also be construed as a nickname, see Introduction 6.1.1.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.

Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 331-2. The name בוטה is recorded on a synagogue inscription from Kafar Kana (OSM, 52, no. 30). בוט is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 74). The name בט is recorded for Arabs (Harding,ICPIANI, 108).On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.
This could also be construed as a nickname, see Introduction 6.1.1.
In tHag 2:11 he is described as a contemporary of Hillel, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.
The identification of this name with Βοηθός, and this family with the Boethus family was suggested by Sukenik, Qobes3 (1934-5) 71-3, see Introduction 3.3. On the ון suffix see Introduction 2.4.3.
On second names see Introduction 6.1.3.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 331-2. The name בוטה is recorded on a synagogue inscription from Kafar Kana (OSM, 52, no. 30). בוט is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 74). The name בט is recorded for Arabs (Harding,ICPIANI, 108).On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.
See above, n. 7. On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

person.note: Thus in Josephus. This name is not recorded in Greek, but the form Χώβαρος is mentioned in WGE, 1696. It is of some interest to note that in BT חובר is used as a title of a Persian priest (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 422).
This could also be construed as a nickname, see Introduction 6.1.1.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

A variant reading in mss has Δάκης. This name is not recorded in Greek. WGE, 265, mention the land of Δακιά. The name Δάκιος is mentioned in LGPN II, 98; III, 105. The name Δακα is recorded among Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 2562).
So according to Epiphanius, in the Syriac script (Wendland, Aristeae, 143), see Introduction 2.8.3. On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.

On Arist see Introduction 6.2.1 and Cohen, JSJ 15 (1984) 35-6. The form Δακιανός is recorded elsewhere in Egyptian antiquity (Preisigke, NB, 82). The form Δακιω is also recorded (Foraboschi, Onomasticon, 89).
For dating of Arist see Introduction 7.1.1.

This name became common in the Greek speaking world, following Alexander’s victory over Darius (WGE, 273). This is the form of this name for the Persian king both in Josephus (Schalit, NB, 37) and in LXX (H & R Suppl. 50).
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

On the interchange of τ and θ see Introduction 2.1.2.3. The word דת as “custom” only appears in the Hebrew Bible in the book of Esther, and probably derives from Persian, see E. Ben Jehuda, A Complete Dictionary of Ancient and Modern Hebrew 2 (London, New York, Berlin 1912) 1011, n. 2.
So according to Epiphanius, in the Syriac script (Wendland, Aristeae, 143), see Introduction 2.8.3. On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.1.
On Arist see Introduction 6.2.1 and Cohen, JSJ 15 (1984) 35-6. This name is not recorded elsewhere in Egyptian antiquity.
For dating of Arist see Introduction 7.1.1.

See above, n. 2. On the interchange of τ and θ see Introduction 2.1.2.3. The word דת as “custom” only appears in the Hebrew Bible in the book of Esther, and probably derives from Persian, see E. Ben Jehuda, A Complete Dictionary of Ancient and Modern Hebrew 2 (London, New York, Berlin 1912) 1011, n. 2. This is obviously another suffix suggested for a foreign name.
All figures appearing in apocryphal Christian documents are considered fictitious, see Introduction 6.2.2.
This book all takes place on the year of Jesus’ execution.

The word גדע means “to cut, chop, lop off” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 213). Hachlili, EI 17 (1984) 198, suggested the Hebrew גידע (stump-legged). And see also under גודע (Gode‘a S-H/M). DJD 2, 232, interpret it as a theophoric name deriving from the deity גד.
On second names see Introduction 6.1.3.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.
This is the same name without a declension. Alternatively, the word גוברא means “man, husband” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 217). The Nabataean Γαβερ is recorded (Negev, Qedem 32, n. 2557).
On second names see Introduction 6.1.3.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
Alternatively, the word גופתא/גובתא means “hill” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 217).

Although a Γυφθαῖος is mentioned in BJ 6:92 as one of Yohanan of Gush Halav’s men and a Τεφθαῖος is mentioned in BJ 5:474 as one of Simon bar Giora’s men, I have decided here to unite the two, as does Schalit, NB, 36. The reasons for this decision, are firstly that the name is a variation and secondly, the name is unique and Josephus is prone to onomastic errors in BJ, (Ilan & Price, JQR 84 (1993) 197-8). Schlatter, HN, 39, identifies this name as an abbreviation and Aramization of Αἴγυπτος.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
The name is very unusual. I assume it includes the Persian “Hazār” element. For the use of ע in the transliteration of vowels see under Aquila (L/M).
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
Jews considered this name as part of the Greek heritage, and it was also occasionally used elsewhere in the Greek speaking world (WGE, 1586, LGPN II, 438) and in Egypt (Preisigke, NB, 451).
On dating in 2 Macc see Introduction 7.1.3.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. Jews considered this name as part of the Greek heritage, and it was also occasionally used elsewhere in the Greek speaking world (WGE, 1586, LGPN II, 438) and in Egypt (Preisigke, NB, 451).

person.note: On the non-Hebrew names of the Hasmoneans see Introduction 1.2.4.3.
On second names see Introduction 6.1.3.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

person.bibl: BJ1:109;AJ13:407 (Schalit,NB, 121); bSot(Kosowsky,Babylonico, 402); Diodorus,GLAJJ1, 185; Strabo,GLAJJ1, 282-96; Florus,GLAJJ2, 133; Dio Casius,GLAJJ, 2, 349-57; 4Q332.
person.note: So in Josephus, see above, n. 2. Jews considered this name as part of the Greek heritage, and it was also occasionally used elsewhere in the Greek speaking world (WGE, 1586, LGPN II, 438) and in Egypt (Preisigke, NB, 451).
This is the way the name of the Hasmonean ruler is transliterated in Qumran.
This is the way the name of the Hasmonean ruler is transliterated in rabbinic literature. It appears to have been the standard transliteration of the name, and see below.
Named after his grandfather (Hyrcanus no. 2), see Introduction 3.1.1. See also above, n. 5. On names in the Qumran scrolls see Introduction 3.2.8.

note.ref: See above, n. 7. On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

See above, n. 2. Jews considered this name as part of the Greek heritage, and it was also occasionally used elsewhere in the Greek speaking world (WGE, 1586, LGPN II, 438) and in Egypt (Preisigke, NB, 451).

person.note: Named after a distant relative (probably Hyrcanus no. 3), see Introduction 3.1.3. On Herodian names see Introduction 1.2.4.4.

note.ref: See above, n. 7. On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

See above, n. 2. Jews considered this name as part of the Greek heritage, and it was also occasionally used elsewhere in the Greek speaking world (WGE, 1586, LGPN II, 438) and in Egypt (Preisigke, NB, 451).

person.note: See also above, n. 5.

note.ref: See above, n. 7. On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

person.note: This is the usual reading, but in tKel BB4:14 the spelling is the more common הורקינס, suggesting that we are dealing with someone of this Greek name and not ̓Αρχῖνος (as suggested by Jastrow, DTTBYML367).
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Joshua and Rabban Gamaliel, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 10. This is the way the name of the Hasmonean ruler is transliterated in rabbinic literature. It appears to have been the standard transliteration of the name, and see below.

person.note: Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Joshua, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 10. This is the way the name of the Hasmonean ruler is transliterated in rabbinic literature. It appears to have been the standard transliteration of the name, and see below.

person.note: He is the father of R. Eliezer, see Introduction 7.5.1.1-2.

note.ref: See above, n. 10. This is the way the name of the Hasmonean ruler is transliterated in rabbinic literature. It appears to have been the standard transliteration of the name, and see below.

person.note: Named after his grandfather (Hyrcanus no. 8), see Introduction 3.1.1.
He is R. Eliezer’s son, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.
This is a very unusual form, which seems to transcribe the name back from Hebrew to Greek, see Fritz and Deines, IEJ 49 (1999) 233-4.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

See above, n. 10. This is the way the name of the Hasmonean ruler is transliterated in rabbinic literature. It appears to have been the standard transliteration of the name, and see below. On the displacement of letters, see Introduction 2.7.3.
On dating of the Masada documents see Introduction 7.8.
This is the way the name is recorded in Josephus. Tacitus has “Izates,” see Introduction 2.8.2. WGE, 540, records this name, but only as mentioned in Josephus, indicating that this not a Greek name.
This is the way the name of this person is documented in Gen Rab.
Josephus, BJ 4:567 described him as a native of Adiabene, see Introduction 6.3.1.
See Introduction 6.3.3.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
This declension is recorded in the document. It is probably a scribal error.
See Introduction 6.3.1.1.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
Alternatively, קמצא means “locust” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1386). For the ר suffix, cf. שזפר (Shazfar – S-H/M). Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 343.
This could also be construed as a nickname, see Introduction 6.1.1.
Described in this tradition in association with the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.
The inscription is bilingual. Thus in the Hebrew. Alternatively, קרס means “hook” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1423). For the suffix, see Introduction 2.4.2.
The inscription is bilingual. Thus in the Greek. The missing ρ is obviously a scribal error, see Introduction 2.7.1.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.

Alternatively, קסא/קיסא means “rough edge, chip” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1364). For an interpretation of this as a nickname see Naveh, Mas I, 25. קסא is recorded for Idumeans (AOFCI, no. 44). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.
This could also be construed as a nickname, see Introduction 6.1.1.
On dating of the Masada documents see Introduction 7.8.
This seems a straightforward Hebrew transliteration of the name. Alternatively, כשכש means “to knock, strike, move about” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 676).
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
This seems to be a transliteration of such a name. On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.5.2.
This could also be construed as a nickname, see Introduction 6.1.1.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
Because the name is recorded in Hebrew, the suffix can be influenced by Aramization, see Introduction 2.4.1.
Although יאיר appears second in this inscription, it makes sense that it is the first name, because it is well known, while this one is rather obscure. On second names see Introduction 6.1.3.
On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
Thus in Josephus. This is how this Persian name is transliterated in Greek (WGE, 943).
Thus in rabbinic literature. The identification of this person with the Adiabenese king is obvious.
Thus in Tacitus, see Introduction 2.8.2.
Josephus, AJ 20:32. described him as a native of Adiabene, see Introduction 6.3.1.
See Introduction 6.3.3.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. Thus in Josephus. This is how this Persian name is transliterated in Greek (WGE, 943).

person.note: Josephus, BJ 2:520. described him as a native of Adiabene, Introduction 6.3.1.

note.ref: See above, n. 7. On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
See above, n. 3. Thus in rabbinic literature. The identification of this person with the Adiabenese king is obvious.

person.note: Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Aqiba, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.

Alternatively, the root נתק means “to break loose, tear out” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 945). נתק is recorded as a name for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 765). For the א suffix, see Introduction 2.4.2. For this name see DJD2, 176.
This could also be construed as a nickname, see Introduction 6.1.1.
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

This seems a plausible transliteration. On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.5.2. Alternatively, the root פלך means “to cut out, round” or “district” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1182). פלך is recorded as a name for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 471). Further on this name, see Klein, Lĕšonénu1 (1929) 342.
In Hebrew – על העצים.
This could also be construed as a nickname, see Introduction 6.1.1.
Associated with the Temple, see Introduction 7.5.1.1.

Alternatively, פרטא means “to split open, divide” or “single” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1224). פרט is a name documented in Aramaic from Persian Egypt (TADAE 2, no. 8.4; 4, no. 14.8); for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 465). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.
This name could be viewed as a nickname, even though it is repeated from grandfather to grandson, see Introduction 6.1.1.
See Introduction 7.5.1.4.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. Alternatively, פרטא means “to split open, divide” or “single” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1224). פרט is a name documented in Aramaic from Persian Egypt (TADAE 2, no. 8.4; 4, no. 14.8); for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 465). On the suffix see Introduction 2.4.2.

person.note: Named after his grandfather (Parteh no. 1), see Introduction 3.1.1.
BT (bKet 100a) sees it as proper name. Whether BT invented the grandson, not noticing that פרטא was a nickname, is a legitimate question. And see also בטנית son of אבא שאול בן בטנית (Botnit no. 2).
Described here as a contemporary of Rabbi (=Judah the Patriarch), see Introduction 7.5.2.

This is one of the rare cases of a name serving for both males and females, see Introduction 1.5.2. The name is recorded for amoraim (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 586; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1193). Note that פז means “gold” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1149). Because the name is recorded in Hebrew, the suffix can be influenced by Aramization, see Introduction 2.4.1.
Described in this tradition as a contemporary of R. Judah the Patriarch, see Introduction 7.5.1.4.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. This is one of the rare cases of a name serving for both males and females, see Introduction 1.5.2. The name is recorded for amoraim (Kosovsky, Yerushalmi, 586; Kosowsky, Babylonico, 1193). Note that פז means “gold” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1149). Because the name is recorded in Hebrew, the suffix can be influenced by Aramization, see Introduction 2.4.1.

person.note: On dating of ossuaries see Introduction 7.6.1.
In Egypt the forms ̔Ραζῖδ, ̔Ρασζῖδ, ̔Ράσιος, and ̔Ρᾶσις are recorded on papyri (Preisigke, NB, 353). Alternatively, רזי means “to be strong, hard” in Aramaic (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1464).
On the independence of 2 Macc see Introduction 5.1.2.
On dating in 2 Macc see Introduction 7.1.3.
This is the orthography in Josephus. For the suffix, see Introduction 2.1.2.2. Alternatively, תיבותא means “chest, box, ark” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1663).
This could also be construed as a nickname, see Introduction 6.1.1.
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.
This is the orthography in Eusebius. The name appears to be the same as the previous.
On this date see Introduction 7.4.2.
This is how this Persian name is transliterated in Greek (WGE, 1522-3). Tacitus has “Tigranes,” see Introduction 2.8.2. “Tigrianus” and “Tigrinus” became eventually Roman cognomen, (RNGCL, 412).
On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

note.ref: See above, n. 2. This is how this Persian name is transliterated in Greek (WGE, 1522-3). Tacitus has “Tigranes,” see Introduction 2.8.2. “Tigrianus” and “Tigrinus” became eventually Roman cognomen, (RNGCL, 412).

person.note: Named after his uncle (Tigranes no. 1), see Introduction 3.1.3.
See Introduction 6.3.2. Josephus (AJ 18:141) specifically states that this branch of the Herodian family ceased to follow Jewish practices and ways of life.

note.ref: See above, n. 3. On dating according to Josephus see Introduction 7.2.

person.note: This is an acceptable Hebrew transliteration for such a name. In Esth Rab 1:18 תרדה is used as a name of a Persian ruler. On the יון suffix see Introduction 2.4.3. תירדת is recorded as a name in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 117). Alternatively, תרדא means “beet” in Hebrew (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 1696). תרד is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 131).
This could also be construed as a nickname, see Introduction 6.1.1.
Already in tannaitic literature (Sifre Deut 307) he is viewed as a martyr of the Bar Kokhba Revolt aftermath, see Introduction 7.5.1.2.

DJD2, 177, interpret this as Persian. On the ו suffix see Introduction 2.4.5.1. The name could also derive from the element איש – man (Noth, IPRGN, 138-9). It could also derive from a Greek name beginning with the cluster στ as many words in the rabbinic literature beginning with איסט or איסת or אישט or אישת suggest (Jastrow, DTTBYML, 54-61). It could also derive from the Egyptian “Isis” (“Ast” – Ranke, ÄPN 1, 3-4).
On dating of the Dead Sea documents see Introduction 7.7.

div.note: Persian ( ̓́Αμασις) – Justi, INB, 14. The name אמסם is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 76), but he claims the root of the name is unknown.
Persian (̓Αρσάμης) – Justi, INB, 29. The name ארסם is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 36), but this is probably the Persian name.
On the Persian Baga see Introduction 1.4.1. The names בגבגן and בגבגא are documented in Aramaic in Egypt (TADAE3, no. 3.26; 4, no. 22.12).

Persian, Justi, INB, 57. On the Persian Baga see Introduction 1.4.1. בגדת is documented as a name in Egypt (TADAE2, nos. 2.1, 4.3, 8.2; 4, no. 19.1). בג'דת is recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 93). בגדא, as the name of later Baghdad, is mentioned in bQid 71b.
Persian, Justi, INB, 59-60. On the Persian Baga, see Introduction 1.4.1. The name בגוי is mentioned in the Persian period in the Bible (Neh 7:19).
Persian, Justi, INB, 71. See also Βόης, (Justi, INB, 70). The names בהנה, בהני and בהון are recorded for Arabs (Harding, ICPIANI, 124).
Persian, Justi, INB, 78-80. The name דריוש is mentioned in the Bible for Persian rulers, e.g. Hag 1:1.
Persian (̓Αζαρέθης), Justi, INB, 127-8. He records there many Persian names with the element Hazār. See also Justi, INB, 88, where names with the ̓Εξαρ component are interpreted as the same.

The name is derived from a region in Persia (WGE, 1585-6). Justi, INB, 133, mentions an Arsakid king by the name of ̔Υρκώδης. In Justi, ibid. 355-6, he mentions “Warkaina” as a proper name, probably of the same root. On this name see also Schürer, 1, 201-2, n. 2.
Persian, Justi, INB, 146. He explains the “Yazd”/Ιζατ element in the name as theophoric.
Persian, Justi, INB, 244, and also Πάρθος, which is the origin of the name “Parthians.”

Persian (Τίβεθις) – Justi, INB, 324. WGE, 506, also mentions the fort of Θεβοθών (Θηβηθών) in Persia. I doubt if the names have to do with this place. The name Θαβαθας is recorded for Nabateans (Negev, Qedem 32, no. 2142). The name תבעות is recorded in Palmyra (Stark, PNPI, 116).
